technical-data.invention-title: VERFAHREN ZUM HERSTELLEN EINES METALLBESCHICHTETEN UND HEISSGEFORMTEN STAHLBAUTEILS UND EINES METALLBESCHICHTETEN STAHLBANDPRODUKTS
METHOD FOR MANUFACTURING A METAL COATED AND HOT-FORMED STEEL COMPONENT AND A METAL COATED STEEL STRIP PRODUCT
PROCÉDÉ POUR LA FABRICATION D'UN COMPOSANT EN ACIER MÉTALLISÉ ET FORMÉ À CHAUD ET PRODUIT DE TYPE BANDE D'ACIER MÉTALLISÉ

abstract.p: The present invention relates to a method for manufacturing a metal coated and hot-formed steel component by direct hot-forming techniques and to a metal coated steel strip product for direct hot-forming. Improvements in mechanical properties of the metal coated and hot-formed steel component are difficult to be obtained without weakening the weldability. According to the invention, the grain structure of a metal coated steel strip made of hardenable steel alloy is deformed comprising non-recrystallized grains and a yield ratio (YS/TS) of said steel strip is higher than 0.75. Recrystallization of said grain structure is at least retarded or even totally avoided or leaved out prior to and during applying metal coating on the surface of the steel strip. This kind of material cannot be used in indirect press hardening, but fits excellently to direct hot press forming and provides possibility to affect mechanical properties without weakening weldability.

The present invention relates to a method for manufacturing a metal coated and hot-formed steel component by direct hot-forming techniques and to a metal coated steel strip product for direct hot-forming. Improvements in mechanical properties of the metal coated and hot-formed steel component are difficult to be obtained without weakening the weldability. According to the invention, the grain structure of a metal coated steel strip made of hardenable steel alloy is deformed comprising non-recrystallized grains and a yield ratio (YS/TS) of said steel strip is higher than 0.75. Recrystallization of said grain structure is at least retarded or even totally avoided or leaved out prior to and during applying metal coating on the surface of the steel strip. This kind of material cannot be used in indirect press hardening, but fits excellently to direct hot press forming and provides possibility to affect mechanical properties without weakening weldability.

La présente invention porte sur un procédé pour la fabrication d'un composant en acier métallisé et thermoformé par des techniques de thermoformage direct et sur un produit de type bande d'acier métallisé pour thermoformage direct. Des améliorations dans les propriétés mécaniques du composant en acier métallisé et thermoformé sont difficiles à obtenir sans baisser la soudabilité. Selon l'invention, la texture d'une bande d'acier métallisé constituée d'alliage d'acier à capacité de trempe est déformée pour comprendre des particules non recristallisées et un rapport de limite élastique (limite d'élasticité conventionnelle (YS)/résistance à la traction (TS)) de ladite bande d'acier est supérieur à 0,75. La recristallisation de ladite texture est au moins retardée ou même totalement évitée ou omise avant et pendant l'application de revêtement métallique sur la surface de la bande d'acier. Ce type de matériau ne peut être utilisé en thermoformage indirect, mais convient parfaitement au formage direct par compression à chaud et offre la possibilité de modifier les propriétés mécaniques sans baisser la soudabilité.

La présente invention porte sur un procédé pour la fabrication d'un composant en acier métallisé et thermoformé par des techniques de thermoformage direct et sur un produit de type bande d'acier métallisé pour thermoformage direct. Des améliorations dans les propriétés mécaniques du composant en acier métallisé et thermoformé sont difficiles à obtenir sans baisser la soudabilité. Selon l'invention, la texture d'une bande d'acier métallisé constituée d'alliage d'acier à capacité de trempe est déformée pour comprendre des particules non recristallisées et un rapport de limite élastique (limite d'élasticité conventionnelle (YS)/résistance à la traction (TS)) de ladite bande d'acier est supérieur à 0,75. La recristallisation de ladite texture est au moins retardée ou même totalement évitée ou omise avant et pendant l'application de revêtement métallique sur la surface de la bande d'acier. Ce type de matériau ne peut être utilisé en thermoformage indirect, mais convient parfaitement au formage direct par compression à chaud et offre la possibilité de modifier les propriétés mécaniques sans baisser la soudabilité.

description.p: Method for manufacturing a metal coated and hot-formed steel component and a metal coated steel strip product

The present invention relates to a method for manufacturing a metal coated and hot-formed steel component by direct hot-forming techniques and especially to such a method according to the independent claim 1.
The present invention further relates to a metal coated steel strip product for direct hot-forming and especially to such a product according to the independent claim 15.
Background of the invention

Hot-forming for producing ultra-high strength steel components especially for automotive industry is a well-established process. As a term, hot- forming includes several terms such as hot-stamping or hot-press forming. When metallurgical phase transformations are also considered, additional terms such as die quenching and press hardening are commonly used. Most common practice is the direct hot-forming, in which the shapes of steel components are formed to the steel sheets at elevated temperatures. In hot-forming process including press hardening, the hardenable steel sheets are hot-formed at high temperature and subsequently quenched with cooled press forming dies. Therefore a steel component gains its shape and mechanical properties in the same and one press. This is an example of the direct hot-forming process including hardening in a press. Alternatively a steel sheet can be first cold- formed to a pre-shaped steel component in a first press and subsequently the pre-shaped steel component is heated and hot-formed in a second press. This latter is so called indirect hot-forming process in which usually most of the deformation is carried out in a cold-forming press.

In general, this hot-forming technique provides several benefits over cold-forming technique, for instance significantly improved formability of steel material at heated state and reduced spring back effect resulting in improved dimensional accuracy of steel components. Also forming at high temperature
requires smaller forming force that results in better material utilization. In addition the steel component still includes some deformation capability even after press hardening. However, this well known hot-forming process has also some disadvantages such as oxide layer that will form on the surface of steel during heating in a non-controlled furnace atmosphere. Non-controlled atmosphere here means that no shielding gas is used. This iron-oxide must be removed before the subsequent coating process and thereby causes increase in costs. Also a bare steel sheet surface can suffer from decarburization during heating that can result in loss of mechanical properties that is unacceptable. These drawbacks have limited wider use of hot-forming process in production of ultra-high strength automotive steel components.

Therefore, in recent years, in order to meet the ever increasing demand for lighter structures in automotive industry, it is established that steel sheets having different metal coatings, such as zinc or zinc based or Al-Si coatings, are suitable for hot-forming. An exemplary patent publication in this regard is EP 1143029 A. It is discovered, that the melting of the coating during austenization of steel is prevented or at least reduced by mutual diffusion between the coating and the iron of the steel sheet. Those coatings are produced by known techniques such as hot-dip galvanization or electroplating and they have the ability to protect the steel surface from decarburization and/or oxidation. Several fresh development efforts have been directed to develop different coatings for hot- forming to meet the challenges in both direct and indirect hot-forming processes. Naturally, in indirect hot-forming, the steel sheet must be formable at room temperature so that cold press forming in the first press is possible. This means that cold-rolled steel strips and sheets must be soft annealed prior to being coated. Usually this is done prior to coating in a continuous annealing process at a temperature higher than a recrystallization temperature, such as at temperatures 700-900 °C for a time required for substantial or complete recrystallization. Therefore, according to the prior art, especially if a steel strip is intended to be used in process including cold-forming, coating is carried out for a soft-annealed steel strip having a microstructure consisting of recrystallized
grains. Therefore also in the later heating step for hot-forming a soft-annealed steel strip was used in prior art.

Welding is the most common joining method for joining this kind of steel components in automotive assembly lines. Especially spot welding is widely used in welding automotive steel components, for instance because it is suitable and fast method for thin steel sheets and can be completely automated. However quick and automated process sets several requirements for the factors affecting weldability of a steel component. For instance general weldability of the steel material should be as good as possible and lower CEV (carbon equivalent) values would be highly desired. Typically commonly used hardenable steels, such as different boron steel grades like 22MnB5, are having quite high CEV values in the range of 0.50-0.55. Especially when hardenable steel grades providing higher strength than typical 22MnB5 are considered, there arises a problem that CEV further increases and weakens the weldability, which is undesired. In addition, while the strength increases, the ductility typically suffers. To sum up, improvements in mechanical properties of the metal coated and hot-formed steel component are difficult to be obtained without weakening the weldability. In addition, different coating systems suffer from several type of cracking problems.
Object of the invention

The object of the present invention is firstly to provide a metal coated steel strip for direct hot-forming and secondly to provide a method for manufacturing a metal coated and hot-formed steel component that both solve or at least alleviate one or more of problems of prior art.

The object of the present invention is achieved with the method for manufacturing a metal coated and hot-formed steel component according to claim 1. The object of the present invention is also achieved with a metal coated steel strip product according to claim 15. The preferred embodiments of the present invention are disclosed in the dependent claims 2-14 and 16-23.
Short description of the invention

From the standpoints presented above, the inventors found that in direct hot press forming, cold-formability is not actually required due to the fact that forming is carried out at elevated temperatures and that the mechanical properties of metal coated and hot-formed steel component produced by direct hot-forming process can be affected without weakening weldability by affecting the initial grain structure of the metal coated steel strip. Therefore the present invention is based on the produced initial grain structure and on the produced yield ratio of the metal coated steel strip product prior to heating sheets for hot- forming.

According to the invention, the grain structure of a metal coated steel strip product for direct hot-forming, made of hardenable steel alloy, is a deformed grain structure comprising non-recrystallized grains and the yield ratio (YS/TS) of the steel strip product is higher than 0.75. Recrystallization of said grain structure is at least retarded or even totally avoided or leaved out prior to, during and also immediately after applying metal coating on the surface of the steel strip.

According to the present invention a step for applying metal coating to the surface of a cold-rolled steel strip is carried out for a steel strip having a deformed grain structure comprising non-recrystallized grains to obtain a metal coated steel strip product still having a deformed grain structure comprising non- recrystallized grains and having a yield ratio (YS/TS) higher than 0.75, and the metal coated steel strip product having the deformed grain structure and the high yield ratio (YS/TS) is used in a heating step for hot-forming.

This kind of steel strip product cannot be successfully used in indirect press hardening, but fits to direct hot press forming and provides possibility to affect the mechanical properties without weakening weldability. This is because highly deformed grain structure comprising non-recrystallized grains include high number of potential nuclei (i.e. nucleation sites) for austenite (γ) grains providing fine grained austenite (γ) as a result of heating for austenization prior to hot- forming and cooling. The higher the volume fraction of non-recrystallized grains
the higher the number of potential initial growing points or nucleation sites for austenite grains. When this kind of metal coated austenitized steel strip product having fine grained austenite (γ) in the microstructure is hot-formed and cooled, especially hot-formed and press hardened, it has been found, that the metal coated and hot-formed steel component can include improved mechanical properties due the finer prior austenite (γ) grains. In the case of hot-forming and press hardening, finer packets and blocks of martensite can form from this kind of prior austenite (γ). This provides the possibility to lower the alloying level and thereby improve the weldability by decreasing CEV without losing the strength. In addition, this kind of steel strip product may provide improved coating characteristics in hot press forming.

Furthermore, the steel strip product according to the present invention is advantageously utilized in quick heating and hot-forming cycle, which makes the production including equipments with different work-cycle times more fluent. However, as the initial prior austenite (y) grain size can be small, the steel strip according to the present invention can be utilized also in typical long lasting, i.e. slow hot-forming cycle. This is because, due to the present invention, the initial prior austenite (y) grain size is smaller which can at least partly compensate the grain growth that can occur in case of prolonged austenizing time in a furnace.

Finally but very importantly, the metal coating applied to a surface of steel strip provides significant technical and economical advantages by obviating the above mentioned iron oxide removing step after hot-forming in a typical non- controlled furnace atmosphere. Furthermore the metal coating can prevent decarburization during the hot-forming process, which could be detrimental for mechanical properties of the hot-formed steel component.
Brief description of the figures

Figure 1 is a schematic drawing of the steps which are included in the method according to the invention.
Figure 2 is a schematic time-temperature drawing (not in scale) of the steps which are included in the method according to the invention.
Figure 3 is a schematic drawing showing few alternative embodiments according to the invention.
Figure 4 is a schematic time-temperature drawing (not in scale) showing features of detailed embodiments according to the invention.
Figure 5 is a schematic time-temperature drawing (not in scale) showing features of other detailed embodiments according to the invention.
Figure 6 is showing the steel product 16 according to the invention.
Figure 7 is showing an evolution of a grain structure recrystallization when the Tmaxi is varied. The picture is taken by an optical microscopy (LePera etching).
Figure 8 is showing a picture of completely non-recrystallized grain structure. Picture is taken by optical microscopy (Nital etching).
Brief description of the reference numbers and terms
1 step 1 for providing a steel strip made of hardenable steel alloy
2 step 2 for cold-rolling
3 step 3 for heating (optional)
3.1 step 3.1 for first annealing (optional)
4 step 4 for applying metal coating
4.1 step 4.1 for applying metal coating by hot-dip coating (optional)
4.2 step 4.2 for electroplating (optional)

5 step 5 for blanking
6 step 6 for heating to a temperature higher than Ad
6.1 first heating section of step 6
6.2 second heating section of step 6
7 step 7 for hot-forming
8 step 8 for cooling
9 step 9 for second annealing (optional)
1 0 deformed grain structure comprising non-recrystallized grains
1 0.1 deformed grain structure comprising non-recrystallized grains without any recovery
1 0.2 deformed and possibly recovered grain structure comprising non- recrystallized grains
1 0.3 deformed and at least partially recovered grain structure comprising non-recrystallized grains
1 1 step 1 1 for third annealing (optional)
12 fine grained prior austenite (γ), i.e. the austenite that has formed during step 6
1 3 step 1 3 for carrying out first preliminary heat treatment (optional)
14 step 14 for carrying out second preliminary heat treatment (optional)
1 5 step 1 5 for cooling (optional)
16 metal coated steel strip product for direct hot-forming, i.e. metal coated hot-forming steel strip product
1 7 blank
theat time calculated from the starting of step 6 to the starting of step 7 Tbath temperature the coating metal or metal alloy in the hot-dip coating bath
max maximum temperature during step 1 3 or 14
Tmaxi maximum temperature during step 3.1
Tmax2 maximum temperature during step 9
Thot-dip temperature of the steel strip during step 4.1

Trx a recrystallization temperature
Ad a temperature at which austenite (γ) begins to form during heating
Ac3 a temperature at which transformation of ferrite (a) to austenite (γ) is completed during heating
A a temperature at which austenite (γ) to ferrite (a) transformation is completed during cooling
ΑΓ3 a temperature at which austenite (γ) begins to transform to ferrite (a) during cooling
Detailed description of the invention

According to the invention, the grain structure of metal coated steel strip product is deformed comprising non-recrystallized grains 10.1 , 10.2, 10.3, and the yield ratio (YS/TS) of the steel strip product is higher than 0.75. Recrystallization of said grain structure is at least retarded or even totally avoided or leaved out prior to and also during applying metal coating on the surface of the steel strip. This can be done for instance, by controlling the maximum heating temperature Tmax, during one or more optional preliminary heat-treatment step(s) carried out after step 2 for cold-rolling but before the beginning of step 6 for heating for austenization, so that Tmax is lower than a recrystallization temperature Tr* of the deformed grain structure comprising non-recrystallized grains. A recrystallization temperature Tre depends, among other factors, on a heating time that in turn is dependent on line speed and length of a production installation. Therefore in step 6, also a steel sheet 17 blanked from said steel strip is having a deformed grain structure comprising non-recrystallized grains and a yield ratio (YS/TS) higher than 0.75 is used.

The mechanism of recrystallization requires a minimum temperature to occur. The recrystallization temperature T^ is a temperature at which grains in the lattice structure of the steel have been re-arranged, leaving the steel free of substantial strains and deformed grains. It is mainly dependent on a heating time and on a cold-rolling reduction rate. Therefore, T^ means the recrystallization
temperature of the deformed grain structure comprising non-recrystallized grains prior to the heat-treatment at issue in each particular case. This temperature can be calculated, in addition to few constant material parameters, based on case- specific heating time and reduction ratio depending on production conditions, for instance. However, as deformed grains include high stored energy state they are thermodynamically unstable. This why, at least partial recovery of deformed grain structure can occur, but the grain structure of metal coated steel strip is still deformed comprising non-recrystallized grains as explained below.

Referring to fig 1 and 2, there are shown the essence of the present invention for manufacturing a metal coated and hot-formed steel component according to the present invention. At the beginning, the steel strip made of hardenable steel alloy is provided in step 1. This steel strip can be obtained for instance by hot-rolling and subsequently pickling the hot-rolled steel strip. The steel strip includes alloying elements in an amount required for desired amount/degree of hardening, i.e. desired amount/degree of martensite transformation, so it is made of hardenable steel alloy. Said steel strip is further subjected to step 2, in which cold-rolling is carried out. This means that during step 2 thickness of the steel strip is reduced. However, even more importantly as stated earlier, this cold-rolling step 2 is essential for the invention especially because it provides the deformed grain structure 10.1 comprising non- recrystallized grains to the steel strip. In this deformed grain structure 10.1 immediately after step 2, the grain structure is not recovered, i.e. it is in so-called full-hard condition. After said step 2 for cold-rolling, the steel strip is subjected to a step 4 for applying metal coating to a surface of cold-rolled steel strip having deformed grain structure comprising non-recrystallized grains 10.1 , 10.2, 10.3. In other words, said step 4 for applying metal coating to the surface of cold-rolled steel strip is carried out for the steel strip having deformed grain structure comprising non-recrystallized grains without any recovery 10.1 , or deformed and possibly recovered grain structure comprising non-recrystallized grains 10.2, or deformed and at least partially recovered grain structure comprising non- recrystallized grains 10.3. Typically and contrary to this invention, i.e. according to
the prior art, especially if the steel strip is intended to be used in a process including cold-forming, as told earlier, this coating step 4 is carried out for soft- annealed steel strip consisting of recrystallized grains in the microstructure. Therefore also in the later heating step 6, a soft-annealed steel strip was used in the prior art. This step 4 provides the corrosion protection layer to the steel product and protects the steel surface from decarburization and/or oxidation during heating involved in the hot-forming process. In essence, step 4 for coating can be carried out by different methods, which few of those are presented later. As can be seen from the figs 1 and 3, the metal coated steel strip product according to the present invention is basically obtained after the step 4. However the step 4 may be followed by step 9 for second annealing, such as galvanneal type annealing (i.e. to form intermetallic compounds comprising iron and coating metal to the coating, shown in fig 4 and 5) and subsequent cooling before the steel strip product is coiled (not shown in the figs). Typically, but not necessarily, steel strip products are delivered from the steel factory in coil form to the site having hot-forming equipments. Also cut to length products, i.e. sheet form is sometimes adequate. Therefore the term steel strip product includes also steel sheets 17, as demonstrated in fig 6.

Referring again to fig 1 , the invented method continues by using the invented metal coated steel strip product 16, which method actually provides the benefits of the invented metal coated steel strip product. Irrespective of the location or delivery format of the steel product, after step 4, the method comprises step 5 in which steel sheets 17 are blanked from said metal coated steel strip product, as shown in fig 6. This can be done by mechanical cutting equipment, for instance. Naturally this blanking step 5 does not affect the grain structure and properties thereof. Thereafter in step 6 the steel sheets 17 are heated to a temperature at which the microstructure comprises austenite (y). This means that the steel sheets 17 are heated to a temperature higher than Aci , preferably higher than Ac3. Preferably in step 6, the whole sheet is heated instead of heating only a local portion of the steel sheet 17. Due to the specific combination of steps 2 and 4, after step 6 there can be obtained fine grained prior austenite (γ) 12 to the
microstructure of the steel sheet 17. In other words, the specific combination of steps 2 and 4 is done in order to obtain fine grained prior austenite (γ) 12 to the microstructure of the steel sheet 17 during and after step 6. Aci is the lower limit because otherwise austenite cannot be achieved. However dual-phase temperature range (Aci to Ac3) can provide, during heating, a dual-phase microstructure having a mixture of fine grained austenite (γ) and elongated ferrite (a) -pearlite grains. Ac3 is the preferably lower limit because this way a maximum amount of martensite can be formed in the microstructure and also the effect of grain refining can be more effective. Also beneficial equi-axial grain structure can be thereby achieved. However the temperature at the end of heating is preferably not higher than Ac3 + 50 °C, preferably not higher than A^ + 30 °C. Therefore step 11 for third annealing after step 6 can be carried out at a temperature in the range 880 to 950 °C. This is because at higher temperature, excessive grain growth may occur. If the steel sheet 17 is heated to a temperature higher than Ac3 but lower than Ac3 + 50 °C a microstructure consisting completely of fine grained austenite (γ) 12 can be obtained. It is also possible that the step 6 for heating comprises a first heating section 6.1 and a second heating section 6.2, as shown in figs 4 and 5. After step 6 for heating, heated steel sheet 17 is hot-formed in step 7. This can be carried out for instance in a press forming apparatus, namely in a hot-press forming apparatus. It must be noted that said steel sheet 17 relates to steel sheet that is not significantly, preferably not at all (pre-) shaped before step 6 or step 7. During this step 7 the steel sheet 17 is hot-formed into a shaped steel component, which has at least partially the shapes corresponding to the shapes of the final steel component. After hot-forming the shaped steel component is cooled in the step 8. This can be carried out in different ways, known in the art, depending on the desired mechanical properties of the steel component. For instance cooling may be carried out by actively cooled pressing dies in a press hardening process. During this cooling step, desired microstructural changes in the steel component takes place. Usually after the cooling step, edge trimming and/or some perforations can be made to the steel component. Also removal of zinc oxides on
surface of the coated steel component may be needed prior to painting. Obtained shaped steel component can hold improved mechanical properties.

It must be noted that in addition to the listed steps in the independent claims, the method can comprise also other steps. However, it must be noted that the steps shown in claims are performed in the given order (or in the given sequence), and between the given steps can exist other steps as shown next.

According to one embodiment, the method comprises also a step 13 for carrying out first preliminary heat-treatment for the cold-rolled steel strip. This first preliminary heat-treatment step 13 is carried out after step 2 and before step 4. Said step 13 is carried out so that the maximum temperature Tmax during this step 13 is lower than a recrystallization temperature of the deformed grain structure including non-recrystallized grains 10.1 , 10.2, in other words Tmax < Τ,χ. This temperature limit provides that even tough the cold-rolled steel strip is subjected to heat-treating, the microstructure still maintains deformed grain structure 10 comprising non-recrystallized grains. In other words, annealing below a recrystallization temperature Trx will substantially preserve the deformed grains caused by cold-rolling. Therefore the metal coated steel strip product preserves also very high yield ratio (YS/TS) as described more detailed later in this description. However, this first preliminary heat treatment is not necessarily needed as explained below.

This first preliminary heat-treatment 13 may be needed in order to improve the adhesion between the metal coating and the steel surface of the cold-rolled steel strip. This is especially the case if the step 4 is carried out by hot-dip coating 4.1 , as shown in figs 3, 4 and 5. Other reason for the first preliminary heat-treatment 13 can be that it may be difficult to be completely omitted or substantially changed in the hot-dip coating line installation. However, in other coating processes, such as in electroplating or thermal spraying (such as high velocity oxygen fuel spraying (HVOF) or gas dynamic cold spray) process, such a first preliminary heat-treatment 13 is not necessarily carried out, as shown in fig 3, but a first preliminary heat-treating may be connected to surface treatments prior to coating step, for instance.
Preferably, said step 4 is carried out by hot-dip coating 4.1 the steel strip in a bath of coating metal. This is because hot-dip coating provides thick coating layers providing excellent corrosion protection performance. Steel components made of hot-dip coated steel strip, especially hot-dip galvanized steel strip, are especially suitable for end products such as automotive vehicles. Furthermore, optional step 9 for second annealing, such as galvanneal type annealing, can be more energy efficiently performed due to the initial elevated temperature of the hot-dip coating process. In other words, in case of hot-dip coating there is needed smaller temperature increment for second annealing. In addition, hot-dip coating may form natural diffusion between the iron of steel and metal of the coating. As shown in fig 4 and 5, during this step 4.1 for hot-dip coating, the pre-heated steel strip is immersed at specific temperature Thot-dip into a bath of liquid coating metal at a specific temperature Tbath- Typically the temperature of the coating metal in the hot-dip coating bath is not more than 100 °C greater than the melting temperature of the coating metal in the bath. The temperature Thot-dip at the moment of immersing the steel strip into the bath is preferably higher than temperature Tbath - 100 °C, more preferably higher than temperature Tbath, as shown in fig 4 and 5. In case of hot-dip coating, this preheating is carried out in step 13 for first preliminary heat-treatment, which includes few embodiments shown below.

According to first embodiment of the method, as shown in fig 4, said step 13 for first preliminary heat-treatment comprises step 3 for heating the cold-rolled steel strip to a temperature Thot-di higher than temperature Tbath - 100 °C, which Tbath is the temperature of coating metal in the hot-dip coating bath, and carrying out step 4.1 for hot-dip coating at this Thot-diP temperature. More advantageously, step 3 for heating the cold-rolled steel strip is carried out to a temperature Thot-dip higher than temperature Tbath. This way the coating adhesion is improved. This first embodiment is preferred because it excludes excessive heat-treatment that can reduce the effect of the present invention due to the recovery and/or recrystallization tendency of cold-rolled steel strip at elevated temperature for long time. Therefore, in this embodiment shown in fig 4, the
advantages of hot-dip galvanized steel product according to the present invention can be emphasized. Typical pre-treatments, such as surface cleaning and/or other surface treatment(s) are preferably carried out for cold-rolled steel strip as usual. However electrolytic cleaning or other methods not requiring significant heating are preferred. These pre-treatments of the surface improve the coating adhesion.

As shown in fig 5, in an alternative second embodiment, said step 13 comprises several steps, which first step is a step 3 for heating the cold-rolled steel strip to a first annealing temperature Tmaxi . Thereafter step 3.1 for first annealing at a temperature Tmaxi in the range 420 to 800 °C, more preferably at a temperature substantially below Ad , such as at a temperature in the range 420 to 695 °C, is carried out. First annealing may be needed in order to pretreat the surface by burners, which is one optional pretreatment method to improve the coating adhesion. Other reason for the step 3.1 for first annealing can be that it may be difficult to be completely omitted or substantially changed in the coating line installation. As can be seen from fig 5, step 3.1 is followed by step 15 for cooling the steel strip to a temperature Thot-dip higher than temperature Tbath - 100 °C, which Tbath is the temperature of coating metal in the hot-dip coating bath and carrying out hot-dip coating at this Thot-dip temperature. More advantageously, step 15 for cooling the cold-rolled steel strip is carried out to a temperature Thot-dip higher than temperature Tbath. This way the coating adhesion is improved. In other words, in this embodiment, the deformed grain structure after cold-rolling can be preserved by lowering the continuous annealing temperature below a recrystallization temperature T,*.

The recrystallization temperature Tre is mainly dependent on a heating time and on a cold-rolling reduction rate and it can be evaluated for instance by Kolmogorov-Johnson-Mehl-Avrami (KJMA) equation that is available in the literature.

Figure 7 is showing an experimental evolution of a grain structure recrystallization when the temperature Tmaxi of first annealing step 3.1 is varied, that step 3.1 was carried out after step 2 for cold-rolling. Pictures are taken by
optical microscopy (LePera etching). Hardenable steel alloy was having the following composition: C: 0.23%, Si: 0.25%, Mn: 1 .25%, Al: 0.03%, Cr: 0.2%, Ti: 0.037% and B: 0.003%. As can be seen from the experiments, when Tmaxi is in the range 420 to 800 °C as in the experiments 1 and 2, deformed and at least partially recovered grain structure comprising non-recrystallized grains 10.3 is obtained. As can be seen, if Tmaxi is higher than 800 °C, like in the experiments 3 and 4 of fig 7, the grain structure comprising non-recrystallized grains 10 is difficult to be preserved and complete recrystallization very easily, if not inevitable, occurs quickly. Grain structures of experiments 3 and 4 are completely recrystallized.

Micro-alloying has been found to retard the complete recrystallization. This is especially needed at temperatures between Ad and 800°C. However, at a temperature above 800°C and with typical carbon content such as around C: 0.25%, austenite (γ) becomes dominant/majority phase and the benefits of the present invention are reduced. The steel strips of experiments 1 and 2 were having a yield ratio (YS/TS) higher than 0.75 and steel strips of experiments 3 and 4 were having a yield ratio less than 0.75.

Figure 8 is showing a picture of the completely non-recrystallized grain structure (Nital etching), which was obtained in experiment 5 by using temperature Tmaxi below 695 °C. Such a steel strip was having a yield ratio (YS/TS) higher than 0.80.

It is preferred that said step 7 for hot-forming is started within 3 minutes calculated from starting of step 6 for heating, i.e. theat≤ 3min. This is because this way finer grained prior austenite (γ) 12 is obtained. This way also cycle times of a heating furnace (an equipment in step 6) and a forming apparatus (an equipment in step 7) are better synchronized with reasonable sized heating furnaces. It is not advantageous to oversize these furnaces, because in case of an interruption in the forming apparatus, such as in case of a tool breakage, all blanks 17 in the furnace would be quickly scrap because of the prolonged heating time which may result in grain growth and coating failures, for instance.
However, as this the initial prior austenite (γ) grain size can be small, the steel strip according to the present invention can be utilized also in typical long lasting, i.e. slow hot-forming cycles. This is because due to the present invention the initial prior austenite (γ) grain size is smaller which can at least partly compensate the grain growth that occurs in case of prolonged austenizing times in the furnace.

It is still more preferred that said step 6 for heating is carried out by using an average heating rate higher than 20°C/s, preferably higher than 30 °C/s. This can be carried out for instance by induction heating equipment, which provides extremely high heating rates. This way the benefits of the present invention are more advantageously achieved, because opportune time for grain growing and/or discharge of dislocations (which provides nucleation sites for austenite (γ) grains) is reduced resulting in finer grain size of austenite (γ). For these reasons, preferably also the step 11 for third annealing, i.e. holding at austenite (γ) range, as shown in fig 4 and 5, is kept short, such as less than 2 minutes or even less than 1 minute. Short holding may be necessary to let some time for austenite (γ) to homogenize, but it should be kept as minimal as possible to avoid grain growth. Therefore, said step 7 for hot-forming can be started within 3 minutes or even within 2 minutes calculated from starting of step 6 for heating, i.e. theat≤ 3 min or even theat≤ 2min. In case of heating rates higher than 100 °C/s, theat≤ 1 min can be obtained which is extremely rapid treating resulting in improvement of mechanical properties. High heating rate results in fluent production flow in a method for manufacturing a metal coated and hot-formed steel component with improved mechanical properties.

As shown in figs 4 and 5, according to one embodiment the step 6 for heating comprises first heating section 6.1 and second heating section 6.2 and that the heating rate of the second heating section 6.2 is lower than the heating rate of the first heating section 6.1. However, the average heating rate of step 6 can be as given above. Lowered heating rate in the second heating section 6.2 improves coating properties during steps 6 and 7 for heating and hot-forming
while higher heating rate in the first heating section 6.1 reduces the discharge of nucleation sites and supports more dense nucleation of austenite (γ).

As can be seen from fig 4 and 5, the method comprise preferably but not necessarily, after step 4 and before step 6, also a step 14 for carrying out second preliminary heat treatment 14 including step 9 for second annealing at a temperature TmaX2 lower than a recrystallization temperature T^ of the deformed grain structure comprising non-recrystallized grains 1 0.1 , 1 0.2, 1 0.3, such as at a temperature in the range 450 to 600 °C. In other words TmaX2 < Trx. However, this step 9 for second annealing can be carried out in any case, in other words irrespective of if or how step 13 and of how step 4 is realized. When this optional second preliminary heat treatment 14 including step 9 is carried out, the metal coated steel strip product and properties therefore are obtained in this step 14. Step 9 can also be called a galvannealing step 9 and it is preferably carried out immediately after step 4 for coating. In case of high heating rate during step 6 and low heating time Wat, this step 9 is especially preferred since it provides iron pre-alloying in the metal coating of the steel strip, which is especially advantageous when benefits of the invention are realized in the step 6 for quick heating disclosed above. As explained above, there is not necessarily overmuch time to wait for suitable iron content to diffuse into the coating metal during step 6 for quick heating or during step 1 1 for third annealing. However, in order to improve hot-formability and quality of the coating, it may be needed to have specific intermetallic compounds and/or solid solutions in the metal coating layer during austenization, especially in the interface between the steel and the coating because this way problems related to LME (liquid metal embrittlement) can be avoided. For this reason, step 9 for second annealing is highly preferred in case quick heating cycles involved in hot-forming the steel product according to the present invention, in other words in case of short theat.

As can be understood from the above, both step 13 for the first preliminary heat treatment and/or step 14 for the second preliminary heat treatment can cause recovery of the deformed grain structure 1 0.1 . However,
even tough some recovery may occur, deformed and recovered grain structure 10.3 still comprises non-recrystallized grains because recovery does not affect essentially the grain shape. Therefore, in step 6 for heating the steel sheet 17 having at least partially recovered and deformed grain structure (10.3) comprising non-recrystallized grains, can be used. Non-recrystallized grains means grains that are having the shape that they have gained in cold-rolling, such as elongated (in the rolling direction) grain shape that is distinguishable from typical soft-annealed equi-axial grain shape of the metal coated steel strip. In other words "non-recrystallized grains" is herein employed to describe the state of a steel sheet which is annealed at a temperature of not higher than a recrystallization temperature so as to avoid a decrease in mechanical strength which usually occurs during heat-treating a cold-rolled steel strip or sheet.

Under certain production conditions, also partial recrystallization of deformed grain structure may occur. Recrystallization can be divided into a nuclei-process and growth-processes. Partial recrystallization can be the case if heating time has been long despite of maximum temperatures Tmaxi and/or Tmax2 of preliminary heat treatments 13,14 have been lower than a recrystallization temperature T x of the deformed grain structure including non- recrystallized grains. Therefore, in step 6 for heating the steel sheet 17 having grain structure comprising, in terms of volume percentages, more than 70% non-recrystallized grains and more preferably more than 95% non-recrystallized grains, can be used. However, most preferably such a steel sheet is used that holds completely non-recrystallized grain structure. Recovery and/or partial recrystallization does not necessarily provide any benefits, but can be unavoidable event under certain production conditions, such as under certain hot-dip galvanizing lines involving heating furnace.

As said earlier, during step 2 the thickness of the steel strip is reduced. Reduction degree is typically 30-95% but preferably 25-65%. This is because lower reduction rates cause less driving force for recrystallization, which can be advantageous especially in case of optional preliminary heat treatment steps 13
and/or 14 are included in the method. However in other cases, also higher reduction rates can be used.

According to one embodiment the cooling step 8 for cooling said shaped steel component is carried out at cooling rate sufficient to induce at least partial, preferably complete hardening of the shaped steel component. Needed cooling rate depends on steel alloy, sheet thickness and degree of hot-forming, but can be such as higher than 10°C/s, or higher than 30°C/s. For instance with 22MnB5 the cooling rate higher than 30°C/s can be required to obtain completely martensitic microstructure. This way ultra-high strength of the steel component is ensured.

According to one embodiment, the step 7 for hot-forming is carried out at a temperature in the range 450-850 °C, preferably 500-700°C, because this way the risk of coating failures caused by LME can be reduced. In addition recrystallization of austenite (γ) grains is avoided resulting in fine prior austenite (γ) grains that are elongated during hot-forming step 7. Lower limits are because otherwise the martensite transformation can start during hot-forming. Upper limits are to ensure above mentioned benefit(s). In this embodiment, the method comprises pre-cooling step (not shown in figs) by using accelerated cooling rate to a hot-forming temperature, which said pre-cooling step is carried before step 7 for hot-forming. This way austenite (γ) decomposition during pre-cooling can be avoided together with suitable alloying.

It is preferred that said step 7 for hot-forming is carried out in a mold of the forming apparatus and that said step 8 for cooling is carried out in said mold. This way dimensional accuracy of the steel component is ensured because the mold prevents dimensional distortions to occur during cooling.

Preferably, said metal coating is a zinc (Zn) based coating. This is because this way the benefits of the invention are advantageously achieved since Zn enables the use of lower coating temperatures, especially in hot-dip coating process due to the relatively low melting temperature of Zn. Furthermore zinc based coating provides galvanic corrosion resistance.
As described earlier, the steel strip is made of hardenable steel alloy. Therefore it may comprise the following alloying in terms of weight percentages:
the balance being iron and unavoidable impurities. In addition some unavoidable residual contents may exist.

Especially in the case of step 4.1 for hot-dip coating including step 13 and/or 14 for preliminary heat-treatments, in terms of mass or weight percentages, 0.01-0.1 % microalloying with one or more of alloying element belonging to the group consisting of titanium (Ti), vanadium (V), niobium (Nb) is preferred because microalloying prevents recrystallization during optional steps 13 and/or 14 for carrying out preliminary heat treatments, by raising a recrystallization temperature Τ„.. In addition, they also hinder austenite (γ) grain growth during steps 6, step 1 1 , and step 7. Therefore, use of microalloying elements is highly preferred especially in case of hot-dip coating but also with other coating methods.

Niobium is found to be a favourable alloying element in the present invention, and therefore such a hardenable steel alloy is used, that contains in terms of weight percentages Nb: 0.005-0.1 %, preferably 0.01-0.08 %, in order to raise a recrystallization temperature Tn< and to control the grain size during austenizing.
The hardenable chemical composition and reasons thereof are more detailed explained later in this description. Next, the product according to the present invention is described in greater detail.

The product according to the present invention is a metal coated steel strip, made of hardenable steel alloy, that product is intended to be used in direct hot-forming, as described earlier. This is because the grain structure of said steel strip is a deformed grain structure comprising non-recrystallized grains 10 and the yield ratio (YS/TS) of the steel strip product is higher than 0.75, as shown in fig 6.

The yield ratio (YS/TS) can be defined based on yield strength (YS) and tensile strength (TS) which are obtainable by commonly known tensile testing. Rp0.2 is preferably used as the yield strength (YS).

Therefore the metal coated steel strip product holds only very small and limited cold-deformation capability and it can be essentially shaped only by hot-forming, i.e. in direct hot-forming process. However, as there is a deformed grain structure comprising non-recrystallized grains 10, there are more nucleation sites for prior austenite (y) in direct hot-forming process and the prior austenite (y) grains can be finer, providing the solution or at least alleviation to the problem of prior art. In addition, this kind of steel strip product can provide improved coating characteristics.

The steel strip product is preferably additionally a cold-rolled steel strip, especially such a cold-rolled steel strip that is cold-rolled by using reduction degree in the range 30-95%, preferably 25-65%. Reduction degree means the reduction percentage of the thickness of the steel strip during cold-rolling. As told earlier cold-rolling was performed in step 2 prior to coating in step 4. Thickness of the steel strip product can be less than 5mm, preferably in the range 0.4 to 2.5 mm.

It is preferred that the grain structure of said metal coated steel strip comprises, in terms of volume percentages, more than 70% non-recrystallized grains and more preferably more than 95% non-recrystallized grains. A method of analyzing the volume fraction of non-recrystallized grains in the grain structure is defined for example in the patent publication WO 2012/053636 A1. Most
preferably the grain structure of said metal coated steel strip is completely non- recrystallized. Also full-hard term may be used. This is because the more non- recrystallized grains and the less recovery, the more nucleation sites for austenite grains. However, the number of nucleation sites can be, in some embodiments, reduced by recovery. Therefore, the grain structure of this metal coated steel strip can be partially or totally recovered like the grain structure 10.3.

As the grain structure of said steel strip is a deformed grain structure comprising non-recrystallized grains, the yield ratio (YS/TS) of the steel strip product is higher than 0.75, preferably higher than 0.80 and most preferably higher than 0.90. A high yield ratio together with non-recrystallized grains provides a high number of nucleation sites for austenite.

Also the yield strength (YS) of said steel strip product is preferably higher than the typical value of such a product, being preferably higher than 550MPa, more preferably higher than 650MPa. The higher the yield strength (YS) and/or the yield ratio (YR), the less recovery and recrystallization of the metal coated steel strip product has occurred which in turn means finer austenite grains. As a comparative example, the typical yield strength (YS) of hardenable boron steel can be in the range 400-450MPa, i.e. lower than 500 MPa. Mentioned strengths are values before step 6 or step 7, i.e. the values of the steel strip product in typical delivery condition from steel factory. As can be understood from this description, preferably the steel strip product is going to be quench hardened in subsequent steps included in hot-forming process, i.e. it is not quench hardened in delivery condition, i.e. prior to being blanked in step 5. In other words, the microstructure of the steel strip 16 or the sheet(s) 17 is preferably a mixed structure of ferrite and pearlite before the heating step 6. After possible quench hardening in step 8, the yield strength (YS) can be higher than 900MPa, preferably higher than 1100MPa.

A deformed and at least partially recovered grain structure comprising non-recrystallized grains 10.3 can be characterized in having a yield ratio (YS/TS) higher than 0.80, preferably higher than 0.90 combined with a total elongation higher than 3%.
As can be understood from above and from figures, the steel strip/sheet 16, 17 is an intermediate product in the method for manufacturing a metal coated and hot-formed steel component. Therefore properties and grain structure of the steel strip/sheet 16, 17 are not the object of the invention but serve as a new way to achieve the object regarding the properties of the metal coated and hot-formed steel component.
Preferably, the hardenable steel alloy, from which the steel strip product is made, comprises in terms of weight percentages the following:
the balance being iron and unavoidable impurities.

Especially in the case of step 4.1 for hot-dip coating including step 13 and/or 14 for preliminary heat-treatments, in terms of mass or weight percentages, 0.01-0.1 % microalloying with one or more of alloying element belonging to the group consisting of titanium (Ti), vanadium (V), niobium (Nb) is preferred because microalloying prevents recrystallization during optional steps 13 and/or 14 for carrying out preliminary heat treatments, by raising a recrystallization temperature T™. In addition, they also hinder austenite (γ) grain growth during steps 6, step 11 , and step 7. Therefore, use of microalloying elements is highly preferred in case of hot-dip coating.
Next the reasons for given hardenable steel alloy above are explained in short. Carbon C is basic element to increase hardenability of steel and it primary determines the hardness and tensile strength of the steel after hardening quenching. Therefore at least 0.08% carbon is preferred, more preferably the lower limit for carbon is 0.15%. However, if the carbon exceeds 0.45%, the weldability will weaken too much. Therefore preferably the upper limit for carbon is 0.3%. Manganese Mn and Chromium Cr are also very efficient elements to increase hardenability and they are preferred to be used so that their sum is in the range 0.5-3.5%. However too high contents may impair ductility and therefore more preferably the sum of Mn and Cr is in the range 0.8-2.0%. Silicon Si is also an element that increases hardenability. In addition it can be utilized as deoxidation agent. However, Si content is preferred to be limited to lower than 1 % since too high silicon would cause surface defects. Most preferably, silicon is alloyed in the range 0.05-0.5%. Aluminium can be alloyed up to 0.2%, but it is more preferably alloyed in the range 0.01-0.15 % or 0.01-0.06 % to serve as de- oxidation agent. Also Nickel Ni and Copper Cu can be utilized up to 1% for increasing hardenability, but their contents are more preferably below 0.5% and below 0.2%, respectively, in order to avoid increase in alloying costs. Boron B is very effective element to increase hardenability with relatively low alloying levels up to 0.01%. The hardenability is very advantageously solved by alloying boron in the range 0.0001 - 0.005%, preferably in the range 0.001-0.005%. In this case it is necessary to alloy also titanium Ti 0.01 - 0.1% to protect boron B from Nitrogen N by forming TiN. If Ti is alloyed more than stokiometric amount in relation to nitrogen (i.e. Ti>3.4N), the excess titanium hinders also coarsening of austenite (γ) grains during step 11 for third annealing, by forming TiC. However, if boron is not alloyed, it is possible to leave out titanium or also alloy Ti up to 0.2% to gain the effects of precipitates. Niobium Nb can be alloyed up to 0.2%, but it is preferably alloyed in the range 0.005 - 0.1 %, even more preferably in the range 0.01-0.08 % in order to raise a recrystallization temperature (Tr*) and to control the grain size during austenizing. Niobium form nitrides, carbonitrides, and/or carbides which hinders recrystallization. Also molybdenium Mo can be alloyed up
to 1% to promote martensite transformation and to raise a recrystallization temperature. However, since Mo is relatively expensive alloying element, it content is more preferably limited up to 0.2%. Vanadium V can be alloyed up to 0.5% to increase hardenability. However, from the alloying costs point of view, V up to 0.2% is preferred. Also it can be utilized as microalloying element in content 0.01-0.1 %. Calsium Ca can be included in the steel due to the possible calsium treatment included in smelt processing. Therefore such as Ca up to 0.01 % or 0.0001 - 0.005% may be included.

Unavoidable impurities can be such as nitrogen N, phosphor P, sulphur S, oxygen O and REM (rare earth metals). Nitrogen N is an element that can bind microalloying elements existing in the steel to nitrides and carbonitrides, thereby it can constitute precipitates. This why, nitrogen content of at least 0.001 % can be included in steel. However, nitrogen more than 0.01 % would allow nitrides to coarsen, and therefore the nitrogen content should be preferably limited to 0.001- 0.01 %. Phosphor P is usually unavoidably included in the steel and can be restricted to 0.06% since higher content can be harmful for ductility. Most advantageously upper limit for P is 0.02%. However, excessive lowering of P may be disadvantageous economically and therefore lower limit 0.005% may be applied. Therefore P content can be 0.005-0.06%. Sulphur S is usually unavoidably included in the steel and can be restricted to lower contents than 0.02%, preferably to lower contents than 0.01 %. However, excessive desulfurization may be disadvantageous economically and therefore lower limit 0.0001% may be applied. Therefore S content can be 0.0001-0.02%. Also oxygen O may exist as unavoidable element in the steel, but can be restricted to less than 0.005%, more preferably less than 0.002%. This is because as it may exist as inclusions that can debilitate properties. REM are preferably allowed not more than typical unavoidable content.

Hardenable steel alloy may also mean that quenching index DlinCh of the steel is equal or higher than 3 as calculated by the known equation available in ASTM A255-67.
Metal coating referred anywhere in this description and claims relate to metal and metal alloy coatings. Similarly zinc based coating relates to zinc and zinc alloy coatings, that are having, in terms of weight percentages, more than 50% Zn in the metal coating.

As can be understood from earlier sections of this description, it is preferred that the metal coating of the metal coated steel strip product according to the present invention is a zinc based coating. In other words, the steel strip is galvanized. Even more preferably the steel strip is hot-dip galvanized.

As a consequence of step 14 for carrying out second preliminary heat treatment including step 9 for second annealing, iron pre-alloying in the metal coating of the steel strip can occur. This means that the iron of the steel strip is diffused into the metal coating, thereby forming different type of iron alloyed metal coating compounds, intermetallic compounds and/or solid solutions. For example Fe-Zn compounds, Fe-Zn intermetallic compounds and/or Fe-Zn solid solutions, can form into the coating as a consequence of step 14 including step 9.

Therefore, according to preferred embodiment, the metal coating of the steel strip is an iron alloyed metal coating, more preferably an iron alloyed zinc coating, such as a galvannealed coating. This means that the metal coating of the steel strip product according to this embodiment (galvannealed coating), can comprise in terms of weight percentages Fe: 5-50% in addition to Zn. Iron (pre-)alloyed zinc coating provides possibility to shorten the heating cycle in hot- forming thereby facilitating the achievement of the effects of the present invention.

In other embodiment metal coating of steel strip is aluminum or aluminium-magnesium alloyed zinc coating. This means that the metal coating of steel strip product according to this embodiment, can comprise in terms of weight percentages, Al: 1-20% and optionally Mg: 1-5% in addition to Zn.

In still another embodiment, metal coating of steel strip is galvanized coating, comprising in terms of mass or weight percentages, Fe: less than 2%, Al: less than 1 % and Zn: higher than 97%.
It will be obvious to a person skilled in the art that, as the technology advances, the inventive concept can be implemented in various ways. The invention and its embodiments are not limited to the examples described above but may vary within the scope of the claims.

claim.claim-text: Claims
A method for manufacturing a metal coated and hot-formed steel component, in which the method comprises the following steps in the given order:
• step 1 for providing a steel strip made of hardenable steel alloy, and
• step 2 for cold-rolling said steel strip to obtain a cold-rolled steel strip having a deformed grain structure comprising non-recrystallized grains, and

• step 4 for applying metal coating to a surface of said cold-rolled steel strip to obtain a metal coated steel strip product (16) still having a deformed grain structure comprising non-recrystallized grains (10.1 , 10.2, 10.3) and having a yield ratio (YS/TS) higher than 0.75, and
• step 5 for blanking a steel sheet (17) from said metal coated steel strip product, and
• step 6 for heating said steel sheet (17) to a temperature higher than Ad, preferably higher than AC3, and
• step 7 for hot-forming the heated steel sheet (17) to obtain a shaped steel component, and
• step 8 for cooling said shaped steel component.

The method for manufacturing a metal coated and hot-formed steel component according to the claim 1 , wherein the method comprises also a step 13 for carrying out a first preliminary heat-treatment for the cold- rolled steel strip, which step 13 is carried out after step 2 and before step 4, and which said step 13 is carried out so that the maximum temperature (Tmax) during this step 13 is lower than a recrystallization temperature (Τ,χ) of the deformed grain structure comprising non- recrystallized grains (10.1 , 10.2), in other words Tmax < Τ„<.

3. The method for manufacturing a metal coated and hot-formed steel component according to claim 2, wherein said step 4 is carried out by hot-dip coating (4.1 ) the steel strip in a bath of coating metal.
The method for manufacturing a metal coated and hot-formed steel component according to claim 3, wherein said step 13 comprises the following step:

• step 3 for heating the cold-rolled steel strip to a temperature (Thot- dip) higher than temperature Tbath - 100 °C, which Tbath is the temperature of coating metal in the hot-dip coating bath, and carrying out step 4.1 for hot-dip coating at this (Thot-dip) temperature.
The method for manufacturing a metal coated and hot-formed steel component according to claim 3, wherein said step 13 comprises the following steps in the given order:
• step 3 for heating the cold-rolled steel strip to a first annealing temperature (Tmaxi ), and
• step 3.1 for first annealing at a temperature (Tmaxi ) in the range 420 °C to 800 °C, more preferably at a temperature below Ad , and

• step 15 for cooling the steel strip to a temperature (Thot-dip) higher than temperature Tbath - 100 °C, which Tbath is the temperature of coating metal in the hot-dip coating bath, and carrying out step 4.1 for hot-dip coating at this (Thot-dip) temperature.

The method for manufacturing a metal coated and hot-formed steel component according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein said step 7 for hot-forming is started within 3 minutes calculated from starting of said step 6 for heating, i.e. theat≤ 3min.
The method for manufacturing a metal coated and hot-formed steel component according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein an average heating rate during said step 6 is higher than 20°C/s, preferably higher than 30 °C/s, and the heating is carried out for instance by an induction heating equipment.

8. The method for manufacturing a metal coated and hot-formed steel component according to any one of the preceding claims 1 to 7, especially according to claims 6-7, wherein the method comprises also, after step 4 and before step 6, a step 14 for carrying out a second preliminary heat treatment including a step 9 for second annealing at a temperature (TmaX2) lower than a recrystallization temperature (T ) of the deformed grain structure comprising non-recrystallized grains (10.1 , 10.2, 10.3), such as at a temperature in the range 450 to 600 °C, in other
WOrdS Tmax2 < ■ rx-

9. The method for manufacturing a metal coated and hot-formed steel component according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein said step 8 for cooling said shaped steel component is carried out at a cooling rate sufficient to induce at least partial, preferably complete hardening of the shaped steel component.

10. The method for manufacturing a metal coated and hot-formed steel component according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein said step 7 for hot-forming is carried out in a mold of a forming apparatus, and said step 8 for cooling is carried out in said mold.
11. The method for manufacturing a metal coated and hot-formed steel component according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein said metal coating is a zinc based coating.

12. The method for manufacturing a metal coated and hot-formed steel component according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein said hardenable steel alloy comprises, in terms of weight percentages the following:
the balance being iron and unavoidable impurities.
13. The method for manufacturing a metal coated and hot-formed steel component according to claim 12, wherein said hardenable alloy further comprises, in terms of weight percentages
0.01-0.1 % microalloying with one or more of alloying element belonging to the group consisting of titanium (Ti), vanadium (V), niobium (Nb).
14. The method for manufacturing a metal coated and hot-formed steel component according to claim 13, wherein said hardenable alloy further comprises, in terms of weight percentages
niobium (Nb) 0.005-0.1 %, more preferably niobium (Nb) 0.01-0.08 %.

15. A metal coated steel strip product for direct hot-forming (16), made of hardenable steel alloy, wherein a grain structure of said steel strip is a deformed grain structure comprising non-recrystallized grains (10.1 , 10.2, 10.3), and a yield ratio (YS/TS) of said steel strip product is higher than 0.75.

16. The metal coated steel strip product for direct hot-forming (16) according to claim 15, wherein the yield ratio (YS/TS)) of said steel strip product is higher than 0.80 and most preferably higher than 0.90.

17. The metal coated steel strip product for direct hot-forming (16) according to claim 15 or 16, wherein a yield strength (YS) of said steel strip product is higher than 550MPa, preferably higher than 650MPa.

18. The metal coated steel strip product for direct hot-forming (16) according to any one of the preceding claims, wherein the grain structure of said metal coated steel strip comprises, in terms of volume percentages, more than 70% non-recrystallized grains, more preferably more than 95% non-recrystallized grains, most preferably the grain structure of metal coated steel strip is completely non-recrystallized.
19. The metal coated steel strip product for direct hot-forming (16) according to any preceding claim, wherein the said hardenable steel alloy comprises, in terms of weight percentages the following:
the balance being iron and unavoidable impurities.
20. The metal coated steel strip product for direct hot-forming (16) according to claim 19, wherein said hardenable alloy further comprises, in terms of weight percentages

0.01-0.1 % microalloying with one or more of alloying element belonging to the group consisting of titanium (Ti), vanadium (V), niobium (Nb). 21. The metal coated steel strip product for direct hot-forming (16) according to claim 20, wherein said hardenable alloy further comprises, in terms of weight percentages

niobium (Nb) 0.005-0.1 %, more preferably niobium (Nb) 0.01-0.08 %. 22. The metal coated steel strip product for direct hot-forming (16) according to any preceding claim, wherein said metal coating is a zinc based coating.
23. The metal coated steel strip product for direct hot-forming (16) according to the claim 22, wherein said metal coating is an iron alloyed zinc coating, such as a galvannealed coating.
